DOC.HEAD: Profit-Taking Cuts Orange Juice Gains in Wild Session
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures prices fell sharply Friday on the New York Cotton Exchange as skittish players took pre-weekend profits in a wild session that featured a one-hour trading halt to prevent mixups in the flood of orders. ``We had a really crazy market here,'' said Celeste Georkakis, an analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc. On other commodity markets, heating oil futures posted fresh gains as the nation's record-setting cold spell continued; precious metals advanced; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Most commodity exchanges held abbreviated trading sessions to give traders and employees an early start on the long holiday weekend. After rising sharply in the four previous sessions, frozen concentrated orange juice futures fell 1 cent to 4.7 cents Friday with the contract for January delivery settling at $1.37 a pound. The runup earlier in the week had been fueled by forecasts for a damaging freeze this weekend in the Central Florida citrus belt, and those forecasts remained in effect on Friday. But many traders fearful of carrying their positions through the three-day weekend opted to take profits rather than risk a market dive when trading resumes on Tuesday. The lowest temperatures were expected to reach Florida on Saturday and Sunday, so the threat of damage to Florida fruit will be long past when the orange juice futures market reopens. The market opened with a surge and quickly rose the permitted 5-cents-a-pound limit for daily trading on heavy speculative buying. But trade selling emerged at mid-morning and speculators joined in, pushing prices nearly limit-down before the exchange called a trading halt at 11 a.m. EST. Heavy selling continued when trading resumed at noon. Heating oil for near-term delivery rose sharply for the sixth straight day and the 17th time in the last 18 trading sessions on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The buying again was linked to weather-driven demand for shrinking supplies of home heating oil. Dealers have reported spot shortages of fuel oil in the heavily populated Northeast, where temperatures have been below normal since late November. Heating oil futures settled .83 cent lower to 1.93 cents higher with January at 81.74 cents a gallon; West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 23 cents to 27 cents lower with February at $21.29 a barrel; unleaded gasoline was .18 cent to .65 cent lower with January at 55.45 cents a gallon. Gold and silver futures rose modestly on New York's Commodity Exchange, reflecting expectations of lower interest rates and a weaker dollar. The Commmerce Department's report of a 5.1 percent rise in factory orders for durable goods last month also was a supportive factor, analysts said. Gold futures finished $1.20 to $1.30 higher with December at $413.20 a troy ounce; silver was 1.6 cents to 1.9 cents higher with silver at $5.56 a troy ounce. Most live cattle and hog futures retreated on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on expectations that warmer temperatures next week in the Great Plains and Midwest will lead to increased livestock marketings. Live cattle settled .25 cent lower to .07 cent higher with February at 76.80 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .08 cent lower to .13 cent higher wiith January at 84.82 cents a pound; live hogs were .60 cent lower to .02 cent higher with February at 48.87 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .42 cent lower to .17 cent higher with February at 49.77 cents a pound. Soybean futures settled moderately lower on the Chicago Board of Trade in quiet, sporadic trading. The grain markets finished nearly unchanged. Analysts said soybeans were pressured by perceptions of improved growing conditions in soybean-growing areas of South America and slack export demand. Wheat futures settled { cent to 1{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $4.11} a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to } cent higher with March at $2.39 a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to \ cent higher with March at $1.54\ a bushel; soybeans were 2\ cents to 3 cents lower with January at $5.72\ a bushel.
